title: 106_hr5097
content: The Act is titled the "Northern Front Range Roadless Area and Mountain Backdrop Protection Act" and it protects roadless areas. The "Northern Front Range Roadless Area and Mountain Backdrop Protection Act" designates certain lands in the Arapaho and Roosevelt National Forests in Colorado as protected roadless areas, including the South St. Vrain Protected Roadless Area and the Fourth of July Protected Roadless Area. The "Fourth of July Protected Roadless Area" in the Mount Evans wilderness includes the South Chicago Creek Protected Roadless Area and the Mount Goliath Protected Roadless Area, totaling approximately 7,496 acres in the Arapaho National Forest. The Chief Mountain Protected Roadless Area comprises 1,038 acres, the Bear Creek Protected Roadless Area comprises 2,787 acres, and the Jones Pass Protected Roadless Area comprises 6,133 acres in the Arapaho National Forest. Certain lands in the Arapaho National Forest and Roosevelt National Forest are designated as protected roadless areas, including Bard Creek, Mt. Sniktau, and North St. Vrain. The Arapaho National Forest and Roosevelt National Forest have designated protected roadless areas, including Bard Creek, Mt. Sniktau, North St. Vrain, and Square Top Mountain. The Secretary of Agriculture will file maps and boundary descriptions for public inspection. The Chief of the Forest Service, Department of Agriculture, will manage identified lands in a manner consistent with the 1997 Revision of the Land and Resource Management Plan for certain national forests and grasslands. Livestock grazing on these lands will follow National Forest System laws. The Secretary of Agriculture must report on the management within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Agriculture will report to Congress on the suitability of identified lands for inclusion in the National Wilderness Preservation System and provide recommendations on their management. SEC. 3. ROCKY FLATS FRONT RANGE MOUNTAIN BACKDROP PROTECTION AREA STUDY. The Secretary of Agriculture, in consultation with State and local agencies, will review specified lands in Colorado and report to Congress on ownership, undeveloped lands at risk of development, and actions to preserve their character. The study area includes lands in southern Boulder, northern Jefferson, and northern Gilpin Counties. The defined area in southern Boulder, northern Jefferson, and northern Gilpin Counties, Colorado, excludes lands within the city limits of Boulder or Golden. Undeveloped land refers to primarily undeveloped open space in the Front Range Mountain Backdrop west of the Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site in Jefferson County, Colorado.
